abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.para: The Z39.86-2011B Primer is a non-normative document that provides an introduction to the technologies and concepts behind the Z39.86-2011 Distribution Framework.

preface.title: Introduction
preface.para: It is safe to say that DTBs have passed the phase of their existence where they can still be called a new technology. DTBs are now ubiquitous, and the technologies they introduced, like the Navigation Control for XML Applications (NCX), have been adopted into other standards, deeply entrenching the specification in the global publishing ecosystem. Even the original expansion "Digital Talking Book" no longer truly encapsulates the breadth of DTBs as an accessible format, but the acronym persists exactly because of the strong association that people now make between it and all forms of accessible publishing.

There is always room to improve and always the need to evolve the DTB specification to keep up with the pace of technological change as the publishing industry moves more deeply into the digital world, however. To keep relevant and to ensure users are still receiving the best possible reading experience, a new revision of the specification was undertaken by the DAISY Consortium. Some of the key issues that this new version of the specification addresses are as follows:

listitem.para: It brings greater distribution flexibility. The new specification allows multiple versions of a DTB to be distributed in a single release, so users can choose which format type they prefer to read.

It brings greater production flexibility. The specification provides greater format diversity, so readers and developers are no longer saddled with SMIL synchronization support when they don't need or use it, for example.

It tightens the scope. The specification no longer tries to be every accessible output in one. Part A of the specification replaces DTBook as a means of facilitating accessible text production and DTBs once again focus on their specific target audience.

It re-aligns the specification with standard technologies. Developers are no longer required to create custom components to process non-standard technologies, such as having to build custom browsers to display content. This change is expected both to simplify the creation of new accessible readers and to facilitate the playback of DTBs in mainstream readers.

preface.para: The Z39.86 Distribution Framework specification is not the optimal place to detail these and other changes that have been implemented, which is where this primer document comes it. This documents represents a simpler entry point into the technologies and concepts for readers who may be new to DTBs or who may produce or distribute DTB content but do not require an intimate understanding of all the requirements and restrictions outlined in the specification.

The primer does not provide any new information that is not already in the specification, but endeavors to present the information in a way that anyone with an interest in DTBs will be able to follow and understand. References to the relevant sections in the specification have been included wherever possible.

chapter.title: What is a DTB?
chapter.para: A DTB, stripped bare, is nothing more than a collection of electronic resources. When taken together, however, those resources allow a document to be rendered in one or more ways conducive to persons unable to read traditional print media. The use of the statement conducive to here is very much intentional, as DTBs are intended to be useful to all digital readers, whatever their abilities.

Persons new to the accessibility field often arrive with the mistaken notion that a format that assists one segment of the population with reading must by necessity come burdened with aids and devices that would limit or exclude its use by another. Nothing could be farther from the truth when it comes to DTBs, however. If anything, the technology was ahead of its time, providing a synchronized text and audio reading experience long before the audiobook and eBook revolution that's taken off in mainstream publishing in the last few years.
There are no limits on what type of document a DTB can represent — books, magazines, articles from journals, a memo to employees, anything that can be written can be converted to a DTB.

A DTB may be distributed as an audio-only publication (a structured "talking book"), a text-only document (e.g. an EPUB document), or it may blend features of both formats (synchronized text and audio). It may also layer video and SVG graphics, thereby enabling a richer multimedia experience. This new version of the specification also allows all of these formats to be combined and distributed in a single publication unit, allowing end users and/or reading systems to pick the most adequate consumption format.
A DTB created in accordance with this standard makes possible a wide range of features:

listitem.para: rapid, flexible navigation (hierarchical or flat-listed);
synchronized playback (e.g. text and audio narration, text and video sign language, etc.);
bookmarking and highlighting;
keyword searching;
spelling of words on demand; and
user control over the presentation of selected items (e.g., footnotes, page numbers, etc.).

chapter.para: Such features enable readers with visual and physical disabilities to access the information in DTBs flexibly and efficiently, and allow sighted users with learning or reading disabilities to receive the information through multiple senses.

chapter.title: What are the DTB types?
chapter.para: Each type of DTB presented in this document offers unique characteristics dedicated to fulfilling specific operational requirements. However, there is also a degree of functional overlap. In order to avoid redundant normative prose in this specification, commonalities are described in independent sections that provide generalized definitions applying to more than one type of DTB. In some cases, the formal definition specific to a type of DTB may enforce particular restrictions to the rules inherited from the generalized definition.
This specification details four types of DTBs:

chapter.title: What's in a DTB?
chapter.para: Although DTBs are made up of many resources, not all DTBs will contain the same types of resources. It is true, for example, that every DTB provides navigation through the inclusion of an NCX file and contains a package file listing its contents, but with four types of DTBs it may confusing to understand why other resources are included in some DTBs and not in others (even within a single DTB type).
Following is a list of the various resources that you may encounter in a DTB, together with a description of their purpose and in which DTB types the are found:

listitem.para: The package file is an XML document that conforms to the Open Packaging Format (OPF) specification and contains administrative information about the DTB.

The package file defines the DTB-level metadata, lists the resources included in the package (the manifest) and defines the default reading order of the document (the spine). For more information, refer to .
You will find a package file in every compliant DTB.

The DTB system supports global navigation — movement by structure (chapter, section, subsection) and by other selected points such as pages, figures, or notes — through the Navigation Control file for XML applications (NCX) (refer to ... for more detailed information).
You will find an NCX file in every compliant DTB.

To synchronize the different media files of a DTB during playback, this standard specifies the use of the World Wide Web Consortium's (W3C) Synchronized Multimedia Integration Language (SMIL), SMIL 3.0 version. The type of DTB determines the subset of SMIL features that are available. Refer to ... for more information.
SMIL synchronization is only found in the Classic and Pro DTB types.

A DTB may include one or more documents containing the text data of the document in (X)HTML5 format. The textual content file enables properly-configured playback devices to spell words on demand, carry out keyword searches, and permit finely-grained navigation. It can also be accessed directly via refreshable Braille display, synthetic speech, or screen-enlarging software.

A DTB may include human or synthetic speech recordings of the document embodied in audio files encoded in one of a specified group of audio formats. Refer to ... for more information about the allowed formats.

In addition to text and audio, DTBs may include images, videos and other multimedia formats that can be presented on players with visual displays. Refer to ... for more information about the allowed formats.
This standard supports user-set, exportable bookmarks and highlights to which text and audio notes can be applied. The format of these files is described in ...

The resource file contains or references various text segments, audio clips, and/or images that provide alternative representations of navigational information — for example, feedback on the user's current location in the document. It supplies information normally presented in a print book via typographical clues.

Given the typically large size of audio files, it is not uncommon for DTBs to span several physical media units. add link describes how the "distInfo" file maps the location of each SMIL file to a specific media unit, e.g., disk 1 of 3. It also explains how, when several books are distributed on the same media unit, the distInfo file stores information about each book for presentation to the reader.
A DTB may also include one or more stylesheets (e.g. CSS) to control the presentation of text and image content in various media.
